channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Many Questions Arise From Scottish Independence Vote
item.description: The referendum itself contains only one question, but it gives rise to many others: What is at stake? What would become of the Union Jack? What would a disunited kingdom be called?
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: At War Blog: A Sister, and Brother, in Arms
item.description: When Teresa Fazio’s brother Mike followed her into the military, the Marine in her was impressed. The sister in her was terrified.
item.dc:creator: By TERESA FAZIO
item.media:description: Teresa Fazio receiving her Marine Corps commission in 2002, with her two brothers, Chris on the left and Mike on the right.

item.title: Egyptian Activist Alaa Abdel Fattah Is Released on Bail
item.description: Mr. Abdel Fattah, a blogger from a prominent family of writers and activists, was jailed under a new law restricting protests but released by a judge who cited potential “embarrassment.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Is Still Open to Talking to Iran About ISIS Threat
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a Paris conference on the Iraqi security crisis, as Iran’s supreme leader said the American plan for bombing ISIS was absurd.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France greeted President Fuad Masum of Iraq at the Elysée Palace in Paris on Monday.

item.title: International Monitors in Ukraine Come Under Artillery Fire
item.description: Six representatives of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe came under artillery strikes in a village south of Donetsk despite the current cease-fire.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Court Confirms 5 Death Sentences in Afghan Rape Case
item.description: Five of the seven defendants in a gang rape case were condemned to death, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Dog Rescues, Chinese Activists Left With a Daunting Task
item.description: Bills keep mounting for animal welfare advocates who have stepped forward to take responsibility for hundreds of dogs recently seized by the authorities in China.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Humane Society International, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescued dogs lie in the shade of a truck that was transporting them to be slaughtered and sold as meat on Aug. 12 in suburban Beijing.

item.title: Wary of U.N. Action, Australia Unveils Plan to Aid Great Barrier Reef
item.description: Hoping to forestall a move by Unesco to put the reef on its list of endangered World Heritage sites, officials said they would set conservation targets.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: The Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change, poor water quality and the impact of coastal development.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Great Unraveling
item.description: A time of weakness and hatred, disorientation and doubt, when nobody can see what disaster looms.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROGER COHEN

item.title: Police Detain Tie Liu, Beijing Writer and Underground Publisher
item.description: After charging the 81-year-old with “creating a disturbance,” officers hauled away computers and his cellphone, as well as books and periodicals.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Burning Man-Style Finale for a Giant Rabbit in Taiwan
item.description: An 82-foot-tall rabbit created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman met with a calamitous end, catching fire as it was being disassembled after drawing huge crowds at an arts festival in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Syrian Leaders See Opportunities and Risks in U.S. Striking ISIS on Their Soil
item.description: Analysts say Syrian officials are unsure who would benefit militarily if the United States launches strikes against ISIS in Syria — government forces, or Syrian insurgents and separatist Kurds.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Hadi Bahra, the president of the opposition Syrian National Coalition, has called for the defeat of ISIS and the government.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Yong Zhao on Education and Authoritarianism in China
item.description: If Western nations fear the rise of an authoritarian and prosperous China, the best thing they can do is not copy its test-driven education system, writes Yong Zhao, since it cannot deliver the creativity the world needs.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Students in the northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang preparing for the university entrance examinations. Critics say the education system in China is overly focused on test scores.

item.title: 41 Dead in Building Collapse at Church Compound in Nigeria
item.description: About 130 people have been pulled out alive since Friday, said a spokesman for state rescuers, whom church members initially kept from the site.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Lost Homes and Dreams at Tower Israel Leveled
item.description: Israel’s destruction of a high-rise, felled in a battle against Hamas, killed no one, but 500 people lost not only their homes, but also a sense of their future.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Explosives Seized and 19 Arrested in Suspected Plot in Uganda
item.description: An imminent attack was expected by a cell of the Shabab, the militant group responsible for the bloody assault on a Nairobi mall last year.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sweden Takes a Left Turn After 8 Years of Rightist Rule
item.description: Swedes rejected austerity and tax-cutting policies that many feared threaten their cherished social-welfare system. At the same time, a far-right party gained substantial ground.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: Stefan Lofven, leader of the Social Democrats and likely Sweden’s next prime minister.

item.title: Cameron Under Pressure as Scotland Vote Nears
item.description: Not only must Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain respond to the beheading of a British hostage by Islamic radicals, but he also faces the risk of becoming the leader who presided over the breakup of the United Kingdom.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: “Yes” and “no” campaign posters in Edinburgh, Scotland, on Sunday. The Scottish independence vote is set for Thursday.

item.title: Arab Nations Offer to Fight ISIS From Air
item.description: American officials have made it clear they do not want the airstrikes to get ahead of the ground action against ISIS, which they said would take time to mass.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMIT.

item.title: Libyan Parliament Fires Central Bank Chairman
item.description: The move by the newly elected Parliament set off a struggle for control of the country’s wealth and vast oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: In Weddings, Pope Francis Looks Past Tradition
item.description: In marrying 20 couples, including some who had already lived together, the pope continued to project the image of a more forgiving church.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis after performing the first wedding in his 18-month-old papacy.

item.title: Syrian Leaders See Opportunities and Risks in U.S. Striking ISIS on Their Soil
item.description: Analysts say Syrian officials are unsure who would benefit militarily if the United States launches strikes against ISIS in Syria — government forces, or Syrian insurgents and separatist Kurds.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Hadi Bahra, the president of the opposition Syrian National Coalition, has called for the defeat of ISIS and the government.

item.title: Scores Feared Dead in Sinking off Libya
item.description: The boat, packed with up to 250 African migrants trying to reach Europe, sank east of Tripoli, and only 26 people have been rescued so far, the Libyan Navy said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Germans Rally to Protest Anti-Semitism Over Gaza War
item.description: Germany’s Central Council of Jews organized the rally in response to the anti-Semitism seen in cities like Berlin after protesters chanting “death to Israel” and “gas the Jews” at pro-Palestinian demonstrations over the summer had deeply unsettled many.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: San Felipe Journal: A Porpoise Is Ensnared by Criminals and Nets
item.description: Fewer than 100 vaquitas are living today, their population nearly wiped out by poachers sweeping up another rare species and shrimp fishermen casting huge nets.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Luis Romero, a fisherman in San Felipe, said it would be a shame to see the vaquita, a snub-nosed porpoise, become extinct. Mexico will limit the size of fishing nets and crack down on poachers to try to save the species.
